supplierActions.finding: Lack of GHG Calculation Understanding at the Plant Level
supplierActions.description: Plant personnel lack awareness of GHG accounting methodologies, leading to inaccurate data and missed reduction opportunities. This poses risks of non-compliance, data inconsistency, and audit challenges. Training on Scope 1, 2, and 3 emissions, standardized data collection, and GHG tracking tools are essential. Regular audits and integration with sustainability goals can enhance accuracy. Immediate intervention is needed to strengthen the plants GHG management capabilities.

supplierActions.finding: Supplier Performance - Gold to Platinum
supplierActions.description: To achieve TVS Supplier Performance from Gold to Platinum, focus on quality excellence, on-time delivery, and other required practices.Adopt sustainable innovations, reduce environmental impact (e.g., minimizing Antimony use), and enhance compliance with ESG standards. Strengthen collaboration with TVS through transparent communication, real-time monitoring, and continuous process improvements.

supplierActions.finding: REcoverability and Recyclability and LCA needs focus implementation at plant level
supplierActions.description:
Recoverability and Recyclability: Implementing waste segregation at the source, setting up closed-loop recycling systems, and using recyclable materials can enhance resource efficiency and reduce landfill waste.

Life Cycle Assessment (LCA): Conducting LCA for materials and processes helps identify environmental hotspots, optimize energy and water usage, and minimize emissions throughout the product life cycle.

Implementation at Plant Level: Integrating sustainable procurement, lean manufacturing, and waste-to-value strategies ensures improved material recovery, cost savings, and regulatory compliance.

Continuous Improvement: Regular monitoring, employee training, and data-driven decision-making can support ongoing optimization of recoverability, recyclability, and LCA-driven sustainability goals.

supplierActions.finding: Manual Working Facility is Unsafe
supplierActions.description:
Lack of Ergonomic Design: Manual working facilities often lead to poor posture, repetitive strain injuries, and musculoskeletal disorders due to inadequate workstation design.

Increased Accident Risk: The absence of mechanized lifting, proper guarding, and automation increases the chances of slips, trips, falls, and manual handling injuries.

Non-Compliance with Safety Standards: Without adequate PPE, safety protocols, and emergency preparedness, manual workstations fail to meet OSHA, ISO 45001, and other regulatory standards.

Productivity and Morale Impact: Unsafe conditions lead to higher absenteeism, low worker morale, and decreased efficiency, ultimately affecting overall plant performance and compliance.

supplierActionHistories.correctiveAction: Reduce manual interventions over time
supplierActionHistories.rootCause: Manual operation
supplierActionHistories.actionTaken:
Ensuring a safe and healthy workplace is paramount at Exide. We've established a proactive, structured framework focused on enhancing safety, minimizing risks, and promoting the comprehensive well-being of all employees.

Employees in high-risk areas receive targeted safety training, and we continuously evaluate and enhance control measures, including engineering, administrative, and PPE, based on risk prioritization.

We continue to upgrade our production with state-of-the-art machinery and automation to reduce manual interventions in the COS and assembly, significantly reducing occupational hazards.

We expect to complete these projects as a part of overall technology upgradation in all Exide factories by the first financial quarter of 2026-27.

supplierActions.finding: Lack of awareness of the fire brigade inlet valve to security team
supplierActions.description: A lack of awareness and coordination regarding the fire brigade inlet valve can delay emergency response. Without a clear protocol, firefighters may struggle to supply water efficiently during critical situations. Poor maintenance or inspection could lead to blockages, leaks, or malfunctions, reducing the effectiveness of fire suppression. If security personnel and responders are not trained on its location and operation, valuable time may be lost during an emergency. To prevent this, a regular maintenance and inspection schedule should be followed to ensure the valve remains functional. Clear signage and easy access must be maintained so firefighters can connect hoses quickly. Joint training and emergency drills will improve coordination between security teams and fire services. Security personnel should also be trained on the valves purpose, location, and proper use to assist in emergencies. Implementing reliable communication methods, such as radios or alarms, will help ensure quick action when the valve is needed. Keeping records of inspections, drills, and corrective actions will improve overall fire safety and emergency preparedness.

supplierActions.finding: The fire pump operator, Vishnu, has two years of experience but lacks knowledge of the fire hydrant system
supplierActions.description: The fire pump operator, Vishnu, has two years of experience but lacks knowledge of the fire hydrant system, working pressure, and its operation. This lack of understanding can create risks during emergencies, as improper handling may lead to delays in firefighting. Without knowledge of working pressure, he may struggle to maintain adequate water flow, reducing the systems effectiveness. His unfamiliarity with hydrant components, such as valves, hose connections, and pump controls, increases the chance of misuse or failure. To fix this, he should receive proper training on hydrant operation, pressure management, and troubleshooting. Regular hands-on drills and supervision by a certified fire safety officer will help improve his skills. Operating manuals, visual guides, and SOPs should be provided for better understanding. Periodic assessments should be conducted to ensure he can operate the fire hydrant system correctly and respond effectively in emergencies.

supplierActions.finding: Absence of a working pressure display board for the hydrant pump system
supplierActions.description: The absence of a working pressure display board for the hydrant pump system can create confusion during emergencies and maintenance. Without clear pressure guidelines, operators may struggle to maintain the correct water flow, leading to ineffective firefighting. This can also increase the risk of system failure due to overpressure or insufficient supply. To address this, a clearly visible pressure display board should be installed near the hydrant pump. The board should include essential details such as normal operating pressure, maximum pressure limits, and safety instructions. Regular inspections should ensure the information remains accurate and legible for all operators.

supplierActions.finding: Absence of safety signages for the PNG gas system and the lack of an authorized entry list
supplierActions.description: The absence of safety signages for the PNG gas system and the lack of an authorized entry list pose serious safety risks. Without proper signages, workers may not be aware of potential hazards, emergency procedures, or necessary precautions. The missing authorization entry list increases the risk of unauthorized personnel accessing restricted areas, leading to potential gas leaks, fire hazards, or operational mishandling. To address this, clear and standardized safety signages should be installed at all critical points of the PNG gas system, indicating hazards, emergency shut-off locations, and necessary precautions. Additionally, an updated authorization entry list should be maintained and displayed to ensure that only trained and authorized personnel have access to the system. Regular audits and monitoring should be conducted to enforce compliance and improve overall safety.

supplierActions.finding: Absence of proper exit signage boards in shop floor areas
supplierActions.description: The absence of proper exit signage boards in shop floor areas can create confusion during emergencies, increasing the risk of delays in evacuation. Without clear exit indications, workers may struggle to find the safest and quickest escape routes, leading to potential injuries or panic in critical situations. To address this, properly illuminated and clearly visible exit signage should be installed at all designated exit points. The signs should comply with safety regulations, including directional arrows and emergency lighting, to ensure visibility even in low-light conditions. Regular inspections should be conducted to maintain signage clarity and effectiveness.

supplierActions.finding: HT hand gloves are expired and require immediate replacement for safety.
supplierActions.otherLaw: Indian Electricity Rules, 1956 (Replaced by CEA Regulations, 2010)
supplierActions.description: The expired electrical license and hand gloves pose a significant safety risk, as unlicensed electrical work and the use of degraded protective equipment can lead to severe accidents, including electric shocks or short circuits. Operating without a valid electrical license may also result in non-compliance with regulatory standards. Expired hand gloves may no longer provide adequate insulation, increasing the risk of electrical hazards. To address this, the electrical license should be renewed immediately, ensuring compliance with safety regulations. Additionally, all expired hand gloves should be replaced with certified, high-quality insulated gloves suitable for electrical work. Regular inspections should be conducted to monitor the validity of licenses and the condition of personal protective equipment (PPE).

supplierActions.finding: Waste storage area is in poor condition and does not comply with hazardous waste regulations
supplierActions.description: The waste storage area is in poor condition and does not comply with hazardous waste regulations, posing environmental and safety risks. Improper waste management can lead to leaks, contamination, fire hazards, and regulatory violations. The absence of proper labeling, segregation, and containment may increase the risk of exposure to harmful substances. To address this, the waste storage area should be cleaned, organized, and maintained as per hazardous waste handling guidelines. Proper waste segregation should be implemented, and clearly labeled containers should be used to store different types of waste safely. Secondary containment measures should be in place to prevent spills or leaks. Regular inspections and audits should be conducted to ensure compliance with hazardous waste management regulations.

supplierActions.finding: Used oil at the DG set is not properly stored, leading to excessive spillage, lack of Form 8 labeling, and the absence of a secondary container
supplierActions.description:
The used oil at the DG set is not properly stored, leading to excessive spillage, lack of Form 8 labeling, and the absence of a secondary container. This poor handling poses environmental and safety risks, including soil and water contamination, fire hazards, and non-compliance with hazardous waste regulations. Improper storage increases the risk of accidental leaks, exposure, and operational hazards.

To address this, used oil should be stored in designated, leak-proof containers with proper Form 8 labeling as per hazardous waste management rules. A secondary containment system (such as a spill tray or bund wall) should be installed to prevent spills from spreading. The storage area should be properly maintained, and all spills must be cleaned immediately using absorbent materials. Regular training and inspections should be conducted to ensure compliance with environmental and safety regulations.

supplierActions.finding: Absence of confined space identification poses a serious safety risk
supplierActions.description:
The absence of confined space identification poses a serious safety risk, as workers may unknowingly enter hazardous areas without proper precautions. Although a work permit is available, the lack of safety precautions increases the chances of accidents such as asphyxiation, toxic exposure, or entrapment. Failure to follow confined space safety protocols is a violation of workplace safety regulations and can lead to severe injuries or fatalities.

To address this, all confined spaces should be clearly marked with identification signs and hazard warnings. A comprehensive confined space entry procedure must be implemented, including oxygen level checks, ventilation arrangements, proper PPE, and standby rescue teams. Workers must be trained on confined space hazards and safety procedures. Regular audits should be conducted to ensure all necessary precautions are followed before issuing a work permit.

supplierActions.finding: Absence of a Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) procedure and a proper electrical work permit system
supplierActions.otherLaw: Indian Electricity Rules, 1956 (Replaced by CEA Regulations, 2010)
supplierActions.description: The absence of a Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) procedure and a proper electrical work permit system violates OSHA 29 CFR 1910.147 and NFPA 70E, which require proper hazardous energy control. Without LOTO, the risk of accidental energy release increases, leading to electric shocks, arc flashes, or equipment damage. The Factories Act, 1948 and the Electricity Rules, 2005 also mandate proper isolation before electrical work. The lack of a permit system increases the chances of unauthorized work and improper safety measures. To comply with regulations, a LOTO procedure should be implemented to ensure proper de-energization before maintenance. Lockout devices and warning tags must be used to prevent accidental re-energization. An electrical work permit system should be enforced, requiring risk assessment and approval before starting any work. Workers must be trained in LOTO procedures and electrical safety protocols. Regular audits should be conducted to ensure compliance with regulations and prevent safety hazards.

supplierActions.finding: Absence of an authorized entry list for all critical areas
supplierActions.description:
The absence of an authorized entry list for all critical areas poses a serious security and safety risk, as unauthorized personnel may access hazardous or restricted zones, leading to potential accidents, equipment damage, or security breaches. This non-compliance violates workplace safety and security regulations that require restricted access to high-risk areas such as electrical rooms, hazardous material storage, and confined spaces.

To address this, a comprehensive authorized entry list must be created and maintained for all critical areas. Access should be limited to trained and authorized personnel only, with proper records of entry and exit. Clear signage should be placed at entry points, stating access restrictions and required permissions. Regular audits and security checks should be conducted to ensure compliance and prevent unauthorized access.

supplierActions.finding: Improper maintenance of earth pits and the absence of identification
supplierActions.otherLaw: Indian Electricity Rules, 1956 (Replaced by CEA Regulations, 2010)
supplierActions.description: Improper maintenance of earth pits and the absence of identification increase the risk of faulty grounding, electrical shocks, and equipment damage. Poorly maintained earth pits can cause high resistance grounding, reducing protection against electrical faults. The lack of identification makes it difficult to locate and inspect earth pits, leading to non-compliance with safety standards. As per IE Rules, 1956 (Rule 33 & 61A), IS 3043, and OSHA 29 CFR 1910.305, earth pits must be properly maintained, tested regularly, and clearly identified. To comply, they should be cleaned, refilled with salt and charcoal if needed, and routinely checked to ensure proper grounding. Identification plates with pit number, resistance value, and last maintenance date must be installed, and periodic inspections and testing should be conducted to meet safety regulations.

supplierActions.finding: lack of calibration of flow meters
supplierActions.description: The lack of calibration of flow meters can lead to inaccurate measurements, affecting process efficiency, resource management, and regulatory compliance. Uncalibrated flow meters may result in incorrect flow readings, leading to overconsumption, underutilization, or safety hazards in industrial operations. This non-compliance violates standards such as ISO 17025 (Calibration Requirements), OIML R117, and legal metrology regulations, which mandate periodic calibration to ensure accuracy. To address this, scheduled calibration and verification of flow meters should be implemented as per manufacturer guidelines and industry standards. Proper documentation of calibration records must be maintained, and periodic inspections should be conducted to ensure compliance and accuracy in measurements.

supplierActions.finding: STP (Sewage Treatment Plant) and ETP (Effluent Treatment Plant) water test reports are not conducted monthly
supplierActions.description: The STP (Sewage Treatment Plant) and ETP (Effluent Treatment Plant) water test reports are not conducted monthly, leading to non-compliance with environmental regulations. Regular testing is essential to monitor water quality, ensure proper treatment efficiency, and prevent environmental contamination. As per CPCB (Central Pollution Control Board) guidelines, EPA regulations, and local pollution control norms, STP and ETP water quality must be tested at least once a month to verify compliance with discharge standards. To address this, a structured testing schedule should be implemented, ensuring that water samples are analyzed as per regulatory requirements, with proper documentation and corrective actions taken if any parameters exceed the limits.

supplierActions.finding: Scope 1, 2, and 3 emissions mapping and carbon emissions calculation have not been conducted
supplierActions.description: The Scope 1, 2, and 3 emissions mapping and carbon emissions calculation have not been conducted, leading to non-compliance with sustainability and environmental reporting standards. Without proper mapping and calculation, the organization lacks visibility into its direct, indirect, and value-chain emissions, making it difficult to set reduction targets and comply with GHG Protocol, ISO 14064, and regulatory frameworks like SECR and ESG reporting. To address this, a comprehensive emissions assessment should be carried out, identifying sources across Scope 1 (direct emissions), Scope 2 (indirect energy emissions), and Scope 3 (value-chain emissions). Proper monitoring, data collection, and reporting mechanisms should be established, and carbon footprint calculations should be conducted periodically to ensure compliance and drive emission reduction strategies.

supplierActions.finding: Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) of the product has not been conducted
supplierActions.description: The Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) of the product has not been conducted, leading to a lack of data on environmental impact across its lifecycle stages, including raw material extraction, production, usage, and disposal. Without LCA, it is difficult to identify high-impact areas, optimize resource efficiency, and comply with sustainability standards like ISO 14040/14044 and ESG reporting frameworks. To address this, a comprehensive LCA study should be carried out to assess the carbon footprint, energy consumption, and environmental impact of the product. The findings should be used to develop sustainable practices, reduce emissions, and enhance product design to meet regulatory and environmental commitments.

supplierActions.finding: Attendance percentage for sustainability training is very low, and there is no designated sustainability ambassador
supplierActions.description: The attendance percentage for sustainability training is very low, and there is no designated sustainability ambassador, leading to poor awareness and engagement in sustainability initiatives. Without proper training participation, employees may lack the knowledge needed to implement eco-friendly practices, resource optimization, and regulatory compliance. The absence of a sustainability ambassador further weakens leadership and accountability in driving sustainability efforts. To improve this, mandatory sustainability training sessions should be conducted with better participation tracking, and a sustainability ambassador should be appointed to promote awareness, lead initiatives, and ensure alignment with ESG goals and environmental regulations.

supplierActions.finding: Standard PPE for contractors is not provided
supplierActions.description: Standard PPE for contractors is not provided, which poses a serious safety risk and leads to non-compliance with workplace safety regulations. Without proper PPE, contractors are exposed to hazards such as chemical exposure, electrical risks, and physical injuries, increasing the likelihood of workplace accidents. This violates safety standards such as OSHA 29 CFR 1910, IS 2925 (India), and ISO 45001, which mandate the provision of appropriate PPE based on job-specific hazards. To address this, contractors should be provided with standardized PPE as per risk assessments, and compliance should be ensured through regular inspections, training, and enforcement of PPE policies at work sites.

supplierActions.finding: No road safety training provided to workers
supplierActions.description: There is no road safety training provided to workers, which increases the risk of accidents, injuries, and non-compliance with workplace safety regulations. Lack of awareness about traffic rules, pedestrian safety, and vehicle movement in industrial areas can lead to unsafe practices, especially in high-risk zones. This violates standards such as OSHA 1926.21, ISO 39001 (Road Traffic Safety Management), and local transport safety regulations, which mandate safety training for workers exposed to roadway hazards. To address this, regular road safety training sessions should be conducted, covering safe walking zones, vehicle movement protocols, emergency procedures, and PPE requirements to ensure a safer working environment.

supplierActions.finding: Absence of a safety officer
supplierActions.description: The absence of a safety officer in the workplace leads to non-compliance with occupational safety regulations and increases the risk of accidents, unsafe practices, and lack of proper hazard management. As per Factories Act, 1948 (India)  Section 40B, OSHA 29 CFR 1910, and ISO 45001, a qualified safety officer is mandatory in industrial establishments with a specified number of workers or high-risk operations. Without a safety officer, safety training, risk assessments, and emergency response coordination may be inadequate. To comply with regulations, a competent safety officer must be appointed to oversee workplace safety, conduct regular inspections, enforce safety protocols, and ensure compliance with legal requirements.

supplierActions.description: During the audit, it was observed that the consent order is not displayed in prominent locations within the plant. As per regulatory requirements, the consent order must be visibly posted to ensure awareness among employees, contractors, and visitors regarding the plants compliance with environmental norms. However, no such display was found in easily accessible or high-visibility areas such as the main entrance, notice boards, or operational zones. The absence of the consent order in prominent locations may lead to non-compliance with regulatory expectations and limit awareness of key environmental and operational conditions among stakeholders.

supplierActions.finding: External Issue Register is not maintaind at the site
supplierActions.description:

The absence of this register indicates a lack of systematic record-keeping, which may lead to gaps in addressing external concerns effectively.

supplierActions.finding: Waste management, including proper handling, segregation, and disposal of hazardous and non-hazardous materials, is not being followed by employees at the site.
supplierActions.description:

Waste segregation is not being implemented effectively, with improper disposal observed.
Designated bins for different waste categories are either missing, mislabeled, or not being used correctly.
No documented evidence of employee training on waste management was available.

supplierActionHistories.correctiveAction: Ensure proper waste management practices are followed at the site, including handling, segregation, and disposal of hazardous and non-hazardous materials. and proper Identification of dust bin will be provided.
supplierActionHistories.rootCause: Identification of dust bin was missed out.
supplierActionHistories.actionTaken: All the dust bin are provided with adequate identification and adequate training has been provided for proper disposal of hazardous and non-hazardous waste

supplierActions.finding: Improper Document Control in Record Maintenance
supplierActions.description: The maintenance of the record register lacks proper document control, with inconsistencies in record-keeping and improper filing and storage practices. No structured system was evident for ensuring accuracy, updates, and accessibility of records.

supplierActions.finding: No documented evidence was available to confirm that periodic installation and testing of equipment by the electrical inspector

No maintenance logs records were provided for review.

supplierActions.finding: The training calendar was not evident during the audit for verification.
supplierActions.description:
During the audit, no documented evidence of a training calendar was available for verification. The following gaps were observed:
No formal training schedule outlining planned sessions, topics covered, and timelines.
Absence of records tracking conducted or upcoming mandatory and sustainability-related training.
Lack of centralized documentation, making it difficult to verify training implementation.

supplierActionHistories.correctiveAction: Least thatn 10 Km from both site and All the compliance under the ESI Main plant and S3 are compiled and ESI handled with centralized plant complies all the ESI Act 1948.

supplierActions.finding: The organization lacks authorization under BMWM Rules, 2016, indicating incomplete compliance with bio-medical waste management standards.

The organization should also establish a bio-medical waste management plan, including proper segregation, storage, and disposal procedures, and provide regular training for employees handling such waste. Regular audits and inspections should be conducted to ensure continuous compliance with the BMWM Rules and other environmental regulations. This will help minimize environmental risks and ensure the safe handling of bio-medical waste.

supplierActions.finding: LOTO procedure is not available

It is recommended to develop and implement a proper LOTO procedure as per OSHA's Control of Hazardous Energy (LOTO) Standard (29 CFR 1910.147) or equivalent local regulations. Additionally, appropriate LOTO devices should be provided, and employees should be trained to ensure the safe isolation of hazardous energy sources during maintenance and servicing activities. Regular audits should be conducted to ensure compliance and prevent workplace accidents.

supplierActions.finding: High-tension (HT) hand gloves, manufactured in September 2022, have expired but are still in use
supplierActions.description: The high-tension (HT) hand gloves, manufactured in September 2022, have expired but are still in use, which is a non-compliance with electrical safety standards. As per IS 4770:2019 and OSHA 1910.137, insulating gloves must be periodically tested and replaced as per the manufacturers guidelines. It is recommended to immediately replace the expired HT gloves with new, certified gloves and establish a monitoring system to ensure timely inspection and replacement of PPE to maintain workplace safety.

supplierActions.finding: Hydrant lines are not clean
supplierActions.description: The hydrant lines are not clean, which presents an opportunity for improvement. It is recommended to implement a regular inspection and maintenance schedule for cleaning and flushing hydrant lines to ensure they remain free from blockages and function optimally. Proper upkeep will enhance fire safety preparedness and compliance with fire safety regulations.

supplierActions.finding: Security team is not well-versed with the fire hydrant line and fire hydrant pump system

It is recommended to conduct regular training sessions for the security team on the operation, maintenance, and emergency use of the fire hydrant system. Mock drills and hands-on practice should be included to ensure they can effectively handle fire emergencies, improving overall fire safety preparedness and compliance with fire safety regulations.

supplierActions.finding: Emergency preparedness plan is not available

Regular training, drills, and periodic updates should be conducted to ensure the plan remains effective and all personnel are well-prepared for emergencies.

supplierActions.finding: Mock drills are conducted periodically
supplierActions.description: Mock drills are conducted periodically, ensuring preparedness for emergency situations. Regular drills help employees familiarize themselves with emergency procedures, improve response times, and identify any gaps in the existing emergency plan. This proactive approach enhances workplace safety, compliance with regulatory requirements, and overall readiness to handle fire incidents, medical emergencies, or other critical situations effectively.

supplierActions.finding: standard electrical rubber mat is not available in front of electrical panels
supplierActions.otherLaw: Indian Electricity Rules, 1956 (Replaced by CEA Regulations, 2010)
supplierActions.description: The ISO 15652 standard electrical rubber mat is not available in front of electrical panels, which is a non-compliance with electrical safety regulations. As per IS 15652:2006 and OSHA 1910.137, electrical insulating mats must be installed in front of panels to protect workers from electrical shock hazards. It is recommended to provide and maintain properly rated electrical rubber mats in all required areas to ensure compliance and enhance workplace safety. Regular inspections should also be conducted to ensure the mats remain in good condition.

supplierActionHistories.correctiveAction: New mat purchased based on the recommendation

It is recommended to install illuminated and clearly visible emergency exit direction signages at all critical locations as per National Building Code (NBC) guidelines and OSHA 1910.37. Regular inspections should be conducted to ensure signages remain intact, visible, and functional at all times.

supplierActions.otherLaw: Indian Electricity Rules, 1956 (Replaced by CEA Regulations, 2010)
supplierActions.description: The electrical safety rescue stick is not available, presenting an opportunity for improvement. It is recommended to provide a properly rated rescue stick near high-voltage areas and ensure all personnel are trained in its correct usage to enhance electrical safety compliance and emergency response preparedness.

It is recommended to adhere strictly to FSSAI Food Safety and Standards Regulations, which mandate the use of proper food-grade utensils, such as stainless steel knives, and require workers to follow personal hygiene standards, including wearing hair nets, wristbands, gloves, and clean uniforms. Regular training and monitoring should be implemented to ensure compliance with food safety standards, and routine audits should be conducted to maintain hygiene and food safety practices.

supplierActions.finding: Consent is not displayed at prominent locations
supplierActions.description: The consent is not displayed at prominent locations, which may lead to non-compliance with regulatory requirements. It is recommended to ensure proper visibility of the consent document in key areas to maintain transparency and adherence to regulations.

supplierActions.finding: Organization does not have a secondary container, and significant spillage has been observed in the used oil storage area
supplierActions.description: The organization does not have a secondary container, and significant spillage has been observed in the used oil storage area, leading to environmental and safety risks. As per Hazardous and Other Wastes (Management and Transboundary Movement) Rules, 2016, EPA regulations, and ISO 14001 standards, hazardous waste like used oil must be stored in leak-proof containers with secondary containment to prevent spills and soil contamination. It is recommended to install a proper secondary containment system, conduct regular inspections, and train staff on safe handling and spill response procedures to ensure compliance and environmental protection.

supplierActions.finding: Form 8 label is not available for hazardous waste
supplierActions.description: The Form 8 label is not available for hazardous waste, leading to non-compliance with hazardous waste management regulations. As per the Hazardous and Other Wastes (Management and Transboundary Movement) Rules, 2016, all hazardous waste containers must be properly labeled with Form 8, indicating waste category, type, quantity, and handling instructions. It is recommended to ensure proper labeling of all hazardous waste as per Form 8 requirements, conduct regular audits to verify compliance, and train staff on correct waste identification and documentation to avoid regulatory violations.

supplierActions.finding: Hazardous waste storage record is not available
supplierActions.description: The hazardous waste storage record is not available, leading to non-compliance with regulatory requirements for tracking and managing hazardous waste. As per the Hazardous and Other Wastes (Management and Transboundary Movement) Rules, 2016, organizations must maintain detailed records of hazardous waste generation, storage, transportation, and disposal. It is recommended to implement a proper record-keeping system, ensure timely documentation of waste movement, and conduct regular audits to verify compliance with environmental regulations.

supplierActions.finding: Scope 1, 2, and 3 emissions mapping and emission calculations have not been conducted
supplierActions.description: The Scope 1, 2, and 3 emissions mapping and emission calculations have not been conducted, leading to a lack of visibility into the organization's carbon footprint and non-compliance with sustainability reporting standards. As per the GHG Protocol, ISO 14064, and ESG reporting frameworks, organizations must identify and quantify direct (Scope 1), indirect (Scope 2), and value-chain emissions (Scope 3) to track their environmental impact. It is recommended to conduct a comprehensive emissions assessment, implement a structured data collection process, and regularly monitor and report carbon emissions to ensure compliance and support sustainability initiatives.

supplierActions.finding: Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) of the product is not conducted.
supplierActions.description: The Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) of the product has not been conducted, leading to a lack of data on its environmental impact across various stages, including raw material extraction, production, usage, and disposal. As per ISO 14040/14044 and sustainability reporting standards, conducting an LCA is essential for identifying high-impact areas, optimizing resource efficiency, and ensuring regulatory compliance. It is recommended to perform a detailed LCA study, assess carbon and environmental footprints, and implement strategies for sustainable product design and reduced environmental impact.

It is recommended to increase participation through mandatory training sessions, awareness programs, and incentives, while also tracking attendance and assessing training effectiveness to strengthen sustainability culture within the organization.

supplierActions.finding: ISO 45001 certification is not available
supplierActions.description: The ISO 45001 certification is not available, indicating non-compliance with international occupational health and safety management system standards. Without this certification, the organization may face gaps in risk management, workplace safety, and regulatory compliance. As per ISO 45001 requirements, organizations must establish a structured safety management system, conduct risk assessments, ensure employee training, and implement continuous safety improvements. It is recommended to initiate the ISO 45001 certification process, conduct gap analysis, and implement the necessary health and safety measures to enhance workplace safety and regulatory adherence.

supplierActions.finding: On-the-Job Training (OJT) is not available
supplierActions.description: On-the-Job Training (OJT) is not available, which may result in a lack of hands-on skill development and reduced workplace safety and efficiency. As per ISO 45001 (Occupational Health & Safety) and ISO 9001 (Quality Management) standards, regular OJT is essential to ensure employees are properly trained in job-specific tasks, equipment handling, and safety procedures. It is recommended to implement a structured OJT program, maintain training records, and periodically assess employee competency to improve operational efficiency and workplace safety.

supplierActions.finding: Road safety training needs improvement to enhance awareness, prevent accidents, and ensure better compliance and participation.
supplierActions.description: Road safety training is not available, which increases the risk of accidents, injuries, and non-compliance with workplace safety regulations. As per ISO 39001 (Road Traffic Safety Management), OSHA guidelines, and local transport safety laws, regular training is essential for employees working near or operating vehicles to ensure safe driving practices, pedestrian safety, and emergency response awareness. It is recommended to implement structured road safety training programs, conduct periodic awareness sessions, and monitor compliance to enhance overall workplace safety.

supplierActions.finding: Security team lacks awareness of the fire brigade
supplierActions.description: The security team lacks awareness of the fire brigade, which can lead to delays in emergency response and ineffective fire safety management. As per NBC (National Building Code) guidelines, Factories Act, 1948, and ISO 45001, security personnel must be trained in fire safety protocols, emergency coordination, and firefighting equipment usage. It is recommended to conduct regular fire safety training, establish clear communication protocols between security and the fire brigade, and conduct joint emergency drills to ensure a well-coordinated response during fire incidents.

supplierActions.finding: Mock drills are conducted periodically
supplierActions.description: Mock drills are conducted periodically, which ensures preparedness for emergency situations and compliance with safety regulations. Regular drills help employees respond effectively to fire, chemical spills, and other emergencies, reducing risks and improving workplace safety. This aligns with NBC guidelines, ISO 45001, and OSHA requirements, promoting a proactive safety culture within the organization. It is recommended to continue these drills, document observations, and implement improvements based on drill assessments for enhanced emergency preparedness.

supplierActions.finding: Fire extinguisher Preventive Planned Maintenance (PPM) records do not include the manufacturing date of the fire extinguishers
supplierActions.description: The fire extinguisher Preventive Planned Maintenance (PPM) records do not include the manufacturing date of the fire extinguishers, which can lead to difficulties in tracking service life and ensuring timely refilling or replacement. As per NBC (National Building Code), IS 2190:2010, and OSHA fire safety regulations, fire extinguishers must be clearly labeled with manufacturing dates to monitor their expiry, maintenance schedules, and compliance with safety standards. It is recommended to update all fire extinguisher records with manufacturing dates, conduct periodic inspections, and ensure timely refilling or replacement to maintain fire safety readiness.

supplierActions.finding: Electrical safety hook is missing, posing risks in high-voltage areas.
supplierActions.otherLaw: Indian Electricity Rules, 1956 (Replaced by CEA Regulations, 2010)
supplierActions.description: The electrical safety rescue stick is not available, which poses a serious risk during electrical emergencies, such as electric shocks or arc flashes. As per IS 15230, OSHA electrical safety standards, and NFPA 70E, an insulated rescue stick (live-line tool) is mandatory for safely removing a person from an electrical hazard without endangering the rescuer. It is recommended to procure and place rescue sticks in all high-risk electrical areas, train employees on their proper use, and conduct periodic electrical safety drills to ensure preparedness.

supplierActions.finding: Emergency contact numbers are missing in critical areas
supplierActions.description: Emergency contact numbers are missing in critical areas, which may cause delays in response during emergencies. As per NBC (National Building Code), ISO 45001, and OSHA safety guidelines, emergency contact details must be clearly displayed in all high-risk areas to ensure quick access to fire, medical, and security assistance. It is recommended to install visible emergency contact boards at all critical locations, regularly update the numbers, and conduct awareness training for employees on emergency procedures.

supplierActions.finding: Authorized entry list for critical areas is not available,
supplierActions.description: The authorized entry list for critical areas is not available, which may lead to unauthorized access and potential safety or security risks. As per ISO 45001 (Occupational Health & Safety), OSHA regulations, and industry best practices, restricted areas must have a clearly defined entry list specifying authorized personnel to prevent accidents, security breaches, or operational hazards. It is recommended to maintain and display an up-to-date authorized entry list at all critical areas, implement access control measures, and conduct periodic audits to ensure compliance and workplace safety.

supplierActions.finding: Number of emergency exit signages is insufficient at shop floor
supplierActions.description: The number of emergency exit signages is insufficient, which may cause confusion and delays during evacuations in an emergency. As per NBC (National Building Code), ISO 45001, and OSHA safety regulations, workplaces must have clearly visible, adequately placed, and illuminated exit signages to ensure safe evacuation routes. It is recommended to install additional emergency exit signs in all necessary locations, ensure proper visibility, and conduct regular safety audits to verify compliance and effectiveness.

supplierActions.finding: Cutting Oil waste exceed
supplierActions.description: As mentioned in form 4, Cutting oil limit to dispose is 2o0 KL per annum, however, it has been exceeded to 33.44 KL

supplierActionHistories.correctiveAction:
1. Explore ways to reduce the amount of cutting oil needed, such as improving the efficiency of machining processes.

2.Introduce periodic internal audits quarterly to check against the disposal limit.

3.Ensure all machinery that uses cutting oil undergoes regular maintenance and inspections to prevent leaks, breakdowns, or inefficient oil consumption.
supplierActionHistories.rootCause:
1.A rise in production volume or operational activities that led to more cutting oil being used than initially estimated.

2.Inefficiencies in machine settings that cause higher oil consumption.

3.Equipment failures Leakage that caused excessive oil usage or loss.

4.Insufficient training or awareness among employees regarding proper cutting oil management practices, such as minimizing waste, ensuring proper application, and maintaining machinery in optimal condition.
supplierActionHistories.actionTaken:
1.Conduct training programs for operators and staff on proper cutting oil management, including how to minimize wastage and optimize oil usage.

2.Set up a system to filter, clean, and recondition used cutting oil for reuse.

supplierActions.finding: Fire hydrant pumps lack pressure display board; monitoring not conducted.
supplierActions.description:
The fire hydrant pumps do not have a working pressure display board, and while a register is available, the working pressure is not being checked. This is a non-compliance issue as per fire safety norms outlined in NFPA 20 (Standard for the Installation of Stationary Pumps for Fire Protection) and other local fire safety regulations.

It is recommended to install a working pressure board that clearly indicates the operational pressure of the fire hydrant pumps. Additionally, regular checks should be conducted to monitor the working pressure, and the readings should be logged in the register to ensure the fire protection system is functioning optimally and remains compliant with safety standards.

supplierActionHistories.correctiveAction:
1. Board displayed with big size.
  2. Check monitoring sheet implemented to monitor operational pressure on regular basis.
  3. Dial gauge modified with green marking to monitor operational pressure on displayed/gauge.
supplierActionHistories.rootCause: Fire hydrant working display board was not visible from far location due to small size.
supplierActionHistories.actionTaken: 100% monitoring

supplierActions.finding: Identification of pumps is not visible, and the direction of flow on the hydrant lines is not indicated

supplierActions.finding: Confined spaces unidentifiable, no work permit system for entry.

It is recommended to properly identify and label all confined spaces, implement a work permit system, and ensure that entry into these spaces follows strict safety protocols. Additionally, ensure that workers are adequately trained in confined space safety practices, including the use of personal protective equipment (PPE) and emergency response procedures.

supplierActionHistories.correctiveAction: Identified confined spaces such as STP Tank, ETP Tank, Cooling water Tank, Underground water tank
supplierActionHistories.rootCause: Confined spaces were identified but not displayed with labels.

supplierActions.finding: Scope 3 emissions are not mapped
supplierActions.description:
Scope 3 emissions have not been mapped, which limits the ability to fully understand and manage the organization's carbon footprint. These emissions, which occur across the value chain, are significant contributors to overall environmental impact.

It is recommended to map and track Scope 3 emissions as part of a comprehensive sustainability strategy. This can include emissions from supply chains, employee travel, waste disposal, and product usage. Implementing a system to assess and reduce Scope 3 emissions will support the organization's efforts to achieve sustainability goals and comply with environmental regulations.

supplierActions.finding: Percentage of solar energy usage is currently good
supplierActions.description:
The percentage of solar energy usage is currently good, but there is potential for further improvement. Increasing the use of solar energy will contribute to sustainability goals, reduce dependency on non-renewable sources, and lower carbon emissions.
It is recommended to explore opportunities for expanding solar energy capacity, such as installing additional solar panels or optimizing current systems. This will enhance the organization's commitment to renewable energy and environmental responsibility.

supplierActions.finding: Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) has not been carried out
supplierActions.description:
The Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) of the product is not available, which limits the understanding of the environmental impact throughout the product's lifecycle. LCA is crucial for identifying areas where sustainability improvements can be made, from raw material extraction to end-of-life disposal.

It is recommended to conduct an LCA for the product to assess its environmental impact and identify opportunities for reduction in energy consumption, waste, and emissions. This will support the organization's sustainability efforts and help in making informed decisions for more eco-friendly production processes.

supplierActions.finding: Form 8  label is not available on hazardous waste.
supplierActions.description:
Form 8, as mandated by the Hazardous and Other Wastes (Management and Transboundary Movement) Rules, 2016 (as amended), is not being used for labeling hazardous waste. According to Rule 17(1), all containers and packages of hazardous waste must be labeled using Form 8. Non-compliance with this requirement can lead to regulatory action and pose risks related to improper handling, storage, and transportation of hazardous waste.

Immediate action should be taken to obtain and implement Form 8 for labeling all hazardous waste containers and packages. This includes procuring the correct format of Form 8 as per regulatory requirements, ensuring that all hazardous waste storage areas, transport containers, and disposal units are appropriately labeled, training relevant personnel on the proper use of Form 8 for compliance, and conducting periodic internal audits to verify continued adherence to labeling requirements.

supplierActions.finding: There is no record of the waste storage date available
supplierActions.description:
There is no record of the waste storage date available, making it impossible to confirm whether the waste disposal occurred within the mandatory 90-day period as required by Rule 8 of the Hazardous and Other Wastes (Management and Transboundary Movement) Rules, 2016. Non-compliance with this requirement may lead to regulatory action and ineffective waste management.

Immediate steps should be taken to establish a proper record-keeping system for hazardous waste storage dates. This includes maintaining a log of waste generation, storage, and disposal dates, implementing a tracking system to ensure disposal within the stipulated timeframe, and training personnel on proper documentation practices. Regular audits should be conducted to verify compliance and prevent future lapses.

supplierActions.finding: Scope 1 and Scope 2 emissions are not being mapped
supplierActions.description: The observation that Scope 1 and Scope 2 emissions are not being mapped indicates a gap in the organization's tracking and reporting of direct (Scope 1) and indirect (Scope 2) greenhouse gas emissions. This could lead to non-compliance with environmental regulations and hinder efforts to mitigate the organization's carbon footprint. Immediate action should be taken to establish a system for monitoring and reporting Scope 1 and Scope 2 emissions. This includes identifying all sources of direct and indirect emissions, implementing the necessary tools for tracking emissions from energy consumption, transportation, and other activities, setting emission reduction targets, and regularly reviewing progress. Additionally, training relevant staff to effectively track and manage emissions, as well as conducting periodic audits to verify the accuracy and completeness of emissions reporting, would be essential.

supplierActions.finding: Confined spaces within the facility have not been identified, and essential safety measures, including adequate ventilation and protective equipment, are not in place to ensure worker safety.
supplierActions.description:
The organization has not  identify confined spaces, which results in non-compliance with legal requirements under Section 36 of The Factories Act, 1948 and IS 14489:2018 (Code of Practice on Occupational Safety and Health Audit). The lack of confined space identification poses significant safety risks, including exposure to oxygen-deficient atmospheres, toxic gases, and other hazardous conditions. It is crucial to conduct a thorough mapping of confined spaces within the facility and maintain an updated list.
Conduct a Comprehensive Confined Space Assessment:

Identify and classify all confined spaces within the facility as per The Factories Act, 1948 (Section 36) and IS 14489:2018 guidelines.

Engage safety professionals to assess potential hazards such as oxygen deficiency, toxic gases, and restricted entry/exit points.

Develop a Confined Space Register:

Maintain an updated list of all confined spaces, including their locations, hazards, and access requirements.
Clearly mark confined spaces with appropriate signage and warning labels.

supplierActions.finding: The organization currently does not have a maintained onsite emergency preparedness plan.
supplierActions.description: The organization currently does not have a maintained onsite emergency preparedness plan. Establishing and regularly updating a comprehensive emergency preparedness plan would enhance the organization's ability to effectively respond to emergencies, minimize risks, and ensure the safety of employees and assets. Recommendation: The organization should develop a structured onsite emergency preparedness plan, including risk assessment, emergency response procedures, evacuation protocols, firefighting measures, and regular drills. Regular training and periodic reviews should be conducted to ensure its effectiveness and compliance with legal and safety requirements.

supplierActions.finding: The fire pumps and fire hydrants are not installed in the factory
supplierActions.description:
The factory does not have fire pumps and fire hydrants installed, which is a critical gap in fire safety infrastructure. This lack of essential firefighting equipment reduces the facility's ability to respond effectively to fire emergencies, posing a significant risk to personnel and property.
Recommendation:
Install Fire Pumps & Hydrant System:

Implement a fire hydrant system with strategically placed hydrant points to ensure adequate water supply for firefighting.
Install fire pumps as per NBC (National Building Code), IS 13039:1991, and Factory Act requirements to maintain the required water pressure.

supplierActions.finding: No, trained and certified operators are not deployed for operating forklifts and powered material handling equipment
supplierActions.description:
The organization has not deployed trained and certified operators for operating forklifts and powered material handling equipment. During the audit, it was observed that a forklift operator did not possess a valid driving license, had not received the necessary training, and was not wearing a seatbelt while operating the forklift. This poses a serious safety risk and results in non-compliance with industrial safety regulations.

Recommendation:
Ensure that only trained and certified operators are assigned to operate forklifts and powered material handling equipment.
Maintain updated records of valid licenses and training certifications for all operators.
Provide mandatory forklift operation training, covering safe handling procedures, emergency response measures, and compliance with safety regulations.
Conduct regular refresher training sessions to reinforce safety protocols and best practices.
Enforce the compulsory use of seatbelts while operating forklifts to enhance operator safety.
Implement a pre-use inspection checklist for forklifts to verify compliance with safety requirements before each operation.
Conduct random safety audits to monitor and ensure adherence to forklift operation standards and safety regulations.

supplierActions.finding: Flammable gases are stored as per applicable laws
supplierActions.description: The flammable gases in cylinders are stored in compliance with applicable laws. Additionally, 8 leak detectors are installed, and flame-proof lights have been provided to ensure safety.

supplierActions.finding: Training sessions on Energy Conservation, Waste Management, Road Safety, and Biodiversity Preservation have not been conducted for employees.
supplierActions.description:
There is a lack of structured training programs on energy conservation, waste management, road safety, and biodiversity preservation for employees. Without proper awareness and capacity building, employees may not fully understand their role in sustainability efforts, leading to inefficiencies, non-compliance with environmental regulations, and missed opportunities for resource optimization. 
Recommended Actions: 
1. Energy Conservation Training: Educate employees on energy-saving techniques such as efficient use of lighting and office equipment. Conduct awareness sessions on renewable energy integration, carbon footprint reduction, and energy-efficient workplace practices. Train facility teams on energy monitoring systems and best practices in energy audits.
 2. Waste Management Awareness: Provide detailed training on waste segregation at source, recycling processes, and waste minimization strategies. Implement a zero waste to landfill initiative by engaging employees in proper disposal methods and sustainable alternatives. Conduct practical sessions on E-waste handling, hazardous waste disposal, and composting for organic waste. 
3. Road Safety Programs: Organize defensive driving training, pedestrian safety workshops, and emergency response drills for employees and drivers. Train employees on vehicle maintenance for fuel efficiency and accident prevention. Implement safe commuting guidelines for employees using personal or public transport. 
4. Biodiversity Conservation Training: Educate employees on the impact of industrial activities on local biodiversity and ways to mitigate ecological damage. Conduct tree plantation drives, awareness sessions on wildlife conservation, and sustainable landscaping practices. Train employees on reducing water consumption, preventing soil erosion, and protecting natural resources near operational sites. 5. Integration & Continuous Engagement: Embed sustainability training into the EHS induction program for all new employees. Conduct periodic refresher training and sustainability challenges to encourage active participation. Establish sustainability champions within teams to promote best practices and monitor compliance.

supplierActions.finding: waste management training and awareness
supplierActions.description:
The organization has not conducted waste management training at the plant, leading to improper waste handling in the waste yard. This indicates a lack of awareness among employees about proper waste segregation, disposal, and compliance requirements.
Recommendation:
Conduct regular waste management training sessions for employees to enhance awareness and compliance with environmental regulations.
Implement a structured waste segregation system to ensure proper disposal and recycling of different types of waste.
Designate responsible personnel or a waste management committee to oversee waste handling and ensure adherence to best practices.
Install clear signage and provide waste disposal guidelines at the waste yard to prevent improper handling.
Conduct periodic waste audits to assess compliance and identify areas for further improvement.

supplierActions.finding: The percentage of  recycled material used in final products
supplierActions.description:
The organization utilizes a very minimal percentage of recyclable materials in its operations, indicating limited integration of sustainable resource utilization. The lack of a structured approach to incorporating recycled materials may lead to higher environmental impact and increased reliance on virgin resources.

To enhance sustainability efforts, the organization should evaluate procurement strategies, explore feasible substitutes with higher recycled content, and implement a material recovery and reuse policy to promote circular economy principles. Additionally, engaging with suppliers to source eco-friendly materials and establishing clear targets for increasing the use of recyclable content will contribute to long-term environmental and cost benefits.

supplierActions.finding: Waste management not maintained at the site
supplierActions.description:
The organization has not established a structured and compliant waste management system at the site, leading to serious environmental, health, and safety hazards. The audit findings revealed:
No proper waste segregation practices are in place, with hazardous and non-hazardous waste mixed, increasing contamination risks.
Improper disposal and accumulation of waste in the yard, indicating a lack of adherence to waste handling protocols.
Non-compliance with legal and regulatory waste disposal requirements, which could result in penalties and legal repercussions.
No formal training was provided to employees and contractors on waste handling, posing a risk of mishandling hazardous substances.
Absence of a waste tracking system, leading to an inability to monitor waste generation, disposal efficiency, and environmental impact.




RECOMMENDATIONS:
Immediate waste segregation implementation: Designate clear waste categories (hazardous, non-hazardous, recyclable, general) and enforce strict segregation at the source.
Establish an authorized waste disposal process: Partner with government-approved waste handlers to ensure safe and legal disposal.
Conduct training and awareness programs: Make waste management training mandatory for all employees and contractors handling waste.
Implement a robust waste tracking and documentation system: Maintain records of waste generation, disposal, and recycling to comply with regulatory norms.
Install proper waste storage and disposal infrastructure: Provide sealed and labeled waste bins, hazardous waste storage areas, and regular disposal schedules.
Perform frequent audits and inspections: Conduct monthly waste management audits to monitor compliance and impose penalties for violations.
Set clear waste reduction targets: Define quantifiable goals to minimize waste generation and increase recycling rates, aligning with sustainability commitments.

supplierActions.finding: The organization has not set any  waste intensity reduction plan
supplierActions.description:
The organization has not set any waste intensity reduction plan. There is currently no structured strategy or defined targets to minimize waste generation per unit of production or operational output. The absence of such a plan indicates:

No benchmarking of waste generation against industry best practices.

Lack of initiatives to optimize resource utilization and reduce overall waste generation.

No monitoring or tracking mechanism to assess waste intensity trends and identify areas for improvement.

Missed opportunities for cost savings through waste reduction, recycling, and reuse programs.

Non-alignment with sustainability and environmental responsibility commitments, which may impact regulatory compliance and stakeholder expectations.

It is recommended that the organization establish a waste intensity reduction plan with clear objectives, performance indicators, and action steps to minimize waste impact and drive sustainable waste management practices.

supplierActions.finding: Waste information has not been posted at the company's main entrance
supplierActions.description:
Waste-generated information has not been updated regularly.

Failure to display and update waste-related data as per regulatory requirements can lead to:
Non-compliance with SPCB guidelines, which may result in penalties or legal implications.
Lack of transparency regarding waste generation, disposal, and management practices.
Reduced awareness among employees and stakeholders about the organizations waste management initiatives.

It is recommended that the company regularly update and display waste information at the main entrance in accordance with SPCB guidelines to ensure compliance, enhance transparency, and promote responsible waste management.

supplierActions.finding: The containers holding hazardous waste are not marked as "Hazardous Waste" as per Form-8.
supplierActions.description:
This non-compliance poses significant regulatory and safety risks, including:
Violation of hazardous waste management rules, which can lead to legal penalties.
Increased risk of accidental exposure, mishandling, or improper disposal due to a lack of clear identification.
Compromised workplace safety, as unmarked hazardous waste can endanger employees and emergency responders.

Recommendation:
Ensure all hazardous waste containers are clearly labeled as "Hazardous Waste" in compliance with Form-8 regulations.
Conduct periodic inspections to verify proper labeling and handling of hazardous waste.
Train employees on hazardous waste identification, handling, and regulatory compliance to mitigate risks.

supplierActions.finding: DOJO training center enhances learning with visuals, SOPs, and maintenance models.

supplierActions.finding: Sewage Treatment Plant (STP): flow meters are not installed at both the inlet and outlet points.
supplierActions.description:
The Sewage Treatment Plant (STP) has been installed; however, upon inspection, it was observed that flow meters are not installed at both the inlet and outlet points. The absence of these meters makes it challenging to monitor and measure the inflow and treated outflow, which is essential for ensuring operational efficiency, compliance, and performance tracking.
It is recommended to install flow meters at both points to enable accurate monitoring and data recording. Additionally, the flow meters must be installed and calibrated at least once a year to ensure accuracy and reliability in measurements.

supplierActions.finding: The treated water quality testing is currently conducted only once a year.
supplierActions.description: The treated water quality testing is currently conducted only once a year. However, periodic testing is essential to ensure compliance with regulatory standards, assess the efficiency of the Sewage Treatment Plant (STP), and detect any deviations in water quality parameters. Infrequent testing may lead to undetected issues, potentially affecting environmental compliance and water reuse efficiency. It is recommended to conduct treated water testing at more frequent intervals, such as quarterly or monthly, depending on regulatory requirements and operational needs, to ensure consistent monitoring and timely corrective actions if necessary.

supplierActions.finding: The copy of the consent order is currently not displayed in a prominent location
supplierActions.otherLaw: Water (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act , 1974
supplierActions.description:
The copy of the consent order is currently not displayed in a prominent location, making it difficult for stakeholders, including employees and regulatory authorities, to easily access and verify compliance. Proper visibility of the consent order is essential to demonstrate adherence to environmental regulations and operational transparency.

Recommendation:
It is recommended to display the consent order in a noticeable and frequently accessed location, such as the main entrance, security office, or near the STP control room. Additionally, the document should be protected from environmental damage (e.g., placed in a laminated or framed format) and periodically checked to ensure it remains legible and up to date.

Implementing water neutrality initiatives is crucial for sustainable water management and regulatory compliance. It is recommended that the organization take steps such as:

Installing rainwater harvesting systems.
Enhancing wastewater recycling and reuse.
Implementing water-efficient technologies and practices.
Conducting regular water audits to identify conservation opportunities.

supplierActions.finding: Organization has not obtained the No objection certificate (NOC) for ground water extraction.
supplierActions.otherLaw: Central Ground water Authority (Guidelines to regulate and control ground water extraction in India) 2020
supplierActions.description:

However, there is no clarity on whether the builder has obtained the necessary No Objection Certificate (NOC) from the relevant authorities for groundwater extraction. The organization is currently unaware of the compliance status and has stated that they will check with the builder regarding the NOC.

The absence of a confirmed NOC poses a potential regulatory compliance risk. It is crucial to verify and obtain a copy of the builders NOC to ensure legal authorization for borewell usage. The organization should follow up with the builder promptly and maintain documented proof of compliance to avoid any legal or operational issues in the future.

supplierActions.finding: The organization does not effectively implement the 5S system.
supplierActions.description:
The workstations are congested and not adequately maintained, leading to space constraints on the shop floor. This congestion poses operational inefficiencies and creates challenges for operators, particularly during emergency evacuations, potentially compromising their safety.

Recommendation:
Conduct a detailed space utilization assessment to optimize workstation layouts and improve accessibility.
Implement 5S principles to ensure better organization, decluttering, and space efficiency.
Establish clear and unobstructed emergency exit routes with proper markings and signage.
Introduce periodic inspections and audits to monitor and maintain adequate workspace conditions.
Train employees on workplace ergonomics and safety protocols to enhance efficiency and emergency preparedness.

supplierActions.finding: The Emergency exits have blocked by storing the material boxes (Obstructed evacuation route)
supplierActions.description:
Emergency exits are blocked due to the storage of material boxes, creating a serious safety hazard by restricting escape routes during emergencies. 
Potential Risks:
Obstructed evacuation routes can delay or prevent safe exit during fires or other emergencies.
Lack of proper signage can lead to confusion and panic during an evacuation.
Non-compliance with fire safety regulations may result in legal consequences and penalties.

Recommended Corrective Actions:
Immediately clear all obstructions from emergency exits and enforce a strict no-storage policy in these areas.
Install clear and illuminated directional signage to guide employees toward emergency exits.
Conduct regular safety inspections to ensure exits remain accessible at all times.
Train employees on emergency evacuation procedures and reinforce the importance of keeping exits unobstructed.
Implement strict compliance monitoring to prevent recurrence and align with fire safety regulations.

supplierActionHistories.correctiveAction: Empty boxes are removed and cleared to exit point for movement.
supplierActionHistories.rootCause: The Emergency exits have blocked by storing the Empty returnable boxes.
supplierActionHistories.actionTaken: Weld mesh will be provided in the Emergency Exit point of Empty box storage area.

supplierActions.finding: Many machines lack essential safety controls,.
supplierActions.description: Many machines lack essential safety controls, including defective retractable hand machine devices and poorly maintained electrical control panels at the plant. These critical deficiencies compromise operator safety during human intervention, significantly increasing the risk of accidental injuries, entrapment, and severe workplace incidents.

supplierActions.finding: Lack of Structured Safety Training for Contractors
supplierActions.description:
The organization lacks a structured process for conducting basic induction, on-the-job training, and toolbox talks for contractors before site entry and shift commencement. Many contractor employees, including freshers, are directly deployed at the worksite with only minimal safety training. This gap in training significantly increases the risk of workplace incidents and non-compliance with safety regulations, potentially endangering both personnel and operations.
Recommendation:
Implement a Structured Contractor Training Program  Develop and enforce a mandatory induction training program covering site-specific hazards, emergency procedures, PPE requirements, and safe work practices before deployment.

Conduct Regular Tool Box Talks  Ensure daily pre-shift safety briefings to reinforce key safety protocols, hazard awareness, and work-specific precautions.

Introduce competency assessmentsevaluate contractors' knowledge and skills through assessments before assigning them to tasks, ensuring their readiness for safe operations.
Maintain Training RecordsDocument all training sessions, attendance, and competency evaluations to track compliance and continuous improvement.
Supervise New ContractorsAssign experienced personnel to mentor and oversee freshers during their initial work period to enhance safety and efficiency.

supplierActions.description:
The organization does not ensure the adequate provision of Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) for workers as per IS standards. Several workers were observed without proper PPE, and the available equipment did not fully comply with regulatory requirements. This gap poses a significant risk to worker safety and regulatory non-compliance.

Recommendation:
The organization should conduct a thorough assessment of PPE requirements based on job roles and hazards. Adequate PPE should be procured as per IS standards, and regular inspections should be conducted to ensure proper usage and maintenance. Training sessions should be implemented to reinforce PPE compliance among workers.

supplierActions.description: The condition of powered tools at the site is not adequately maintained, posing potential safety risks. Additionally, portable equipment and hand tools are not inspected at the entry gate or at defined intervals for safety checks, increasing the likelihood of tool-related accidents and failures.

supplierActions.finding: Enhancement of Road Safety Training and Awareness Programs
supplierActions.description:
The organization currently lacks a structured road safety training program for employees and contractors. Additionally, no periodic awareness campaigns or Road Safety Week activities have been conducted. Strengthening road safety initiatives can significantly improve awareness and compliance with traffic safety measures within the premises.

Recommendation:
Introduce a formal road safety training program for all employees, including contractors, with periodic refresher sessions.
Conduct awareness campaigns to reinforce the importance of safe driving, pedestrian safety, and adherence to speed limits.
Organize activities during Road Safety Week to promote traffic safety culture within the organization.
Implement periodic safety audits and enforcement measures to ensure adherence to road safety protocols.

supplierActions.finding: Onsite emergency preparedness plan is not maintained at the plant.
supplierActions.description: The organization currently does not have a maintained onsite emergency preparedness plan. Establishing and regularly updating a comprehensive emergency preparedness plan would enhance the organization's ability to effectively respond to emergencies, minimize risks, and ensure the safety of employees and assets. Recommendation: The organization should develop a structured onsite emergency preparedness plan, including risk assessment, emergency response procedures, evacuation protocols, firefighting measures, and regular drills. Regular training and periodic reviews should be conducted to ensure its effectiveness and compliance with legal and safety requirements.

Recommendation: The organization should install clearly visible evacuation plans across all critical areas of the plant. Regular drills should be conducted to ensure all employees are familiar with evacuation routes and emergency procedures.

Mapping of confined spaces within the facility should be conducted, and a maintained list should be established.

Conduct awareness programs and training sessions for employees to ensure compliance with waste segregation practices.
Establish monitoring and enforcement mechanisms to ensure proper waste handling and disposal
Collaborate with authorized waste management vendors to streamline collection, recycling, and disposal processes.
Periodically review and audit the waste segregation process to identify areas for improvement and ensure regulatory compliance.

supplierActions.finding: The committee consists of 11 members, all selected from plant on-roll employees, without the inclusion of shop floor representatives or employees, which is a deviation from the required composition.
supplierActions.description:
The committee currently comprises 11 members, all selected exclusively from plant on-roll employees. However, as per the stipulated requirements, the committee must include shop floor representatives or employees to ensure fair representation of the workforce. The absence of shop floor employees limits direct input from those actively engaged in operational activities, potentially leading to gaps in workplace safety, process improvements, and employee concerns.

Recommendation:
Inclusion of Shop Floor Representatives: Revise the committee structure to include representatives from the shop floor, ensuring compliance with regulatory and organizational requirements.
Balanced Representation: Maintain a diverse composition that includes employees from different levels and departments to foster inclusive decision-making.
Communication & Implementation: Formally update and document the committee structure, communicating the changes to all stakeholders to ensure transparency and adherence to compliance standards.
Periodic Review: Establish a mechanism for periodic review of committee composition to maintain compliance and effectiveness in addressing employee concerns.
