supplierActions.finding: Lack of Biodiversity Ambassador Program
supplierActions.description:
The organization does not designate any employee as an Ambassador for Biodiversity, which could indicate a lack of structured leadership in biodiversity-related initiatives.
Impact: Missed opportunities for biodiversity awareness and engagement.

 Recommendation: Establish a biodiversity ambassador program or integrate biodiversity stewardship into existing EHS roles.

supplierActions.finding: Absence of Sustainability Training for Employees
supplierActions.description:
No sustainability training programs have been planned or conducted, leading to 0% employee coverage in sustainability education.
Impact: Limited awareness and engagement in sustainability initiatives.

Recommendation: Develop and implement sustainability training modules, ensuring employees are equipped with the necessary knowledge.

supplierActions.finding: Training sessions on Energy Conservation, Waste Management, Road Safety, and Biodiversity Preservation have not been conducted for employees.
supplierActions.description: There is a lack of structured training programs on energy conservation, waste management, road safety, and biodiversity preservation for employees. Without proper awareness and capacity building, employees may not fully understand their role in sustainability efforts, leading to inefficiencies, non-compliance with environmental regulations, and missed opportunities for resource optimization. Recommended Actions: 1. Energy Conservation Training: Educate employees on energy-saving techniques such as efficient use of lighting and office equipment. Conduct awareness sessions on renewable energy integration, carbon footprint reduction, and energy-efficient workplace practices. Train facility teams on energy monitoring systems and best practices in energy audits. 2. Waste Management Awareness: Provide detailed training on waste segregation at source, recycling processes, and waste minimization strategies. Implement a zero waste to landfill initiative by engaging employees in proper disposal methods and sustainable alternatives. Conduct practical sessions on E-waste handling, hazardous waste disposal, and composting for organic waste. 3. Road Safety Programs: Organize defensive driving training, pedestrian safety workshops, and emergency response drills for employees and drivers. Train employees on vehicle maintenance for fuel efficiency and accident prevention. Implement safe commuting guidelines for employees using personal or public transport. 4. Biodiversity Conservation Training: Educate employees on the impact of industrial activities on local biodiversity and ways to mitigate ecological damage. Conduct tree plantation drives, awareness sessions on wildlife conservation, and sustainable landscaping practices. Train employees on reducing water consumption, preventing soil erosion, and protecting natural resources near operational sites. 5. Integration & Continuous Engagement: Embed sustainability training into the EHS induction program for all new employees. Conduct periodic refresher training and sustainability challenges to encourage active participation. Establish sustainability champions within teams to promote best practices and monitor compliance.

supplierActions.finding: Works committee

During the audit, through a personal interview, it was observed that the company is paying only Basic wage and not twice the basic wage. 
Employee Interviewed. - Geetha and Savitha

supplierActions.finding: Working hours
supplierActions.description:

supplierActions.finding: Appointment letter in Kannada
supplierActions.description: It was observed that a few contract employees were issued appointment letters in Kannada

supplierActions.finding: The consent order is not displayed in the prominent locations at the plant
supplierActions.description: During the audit, it was observed that the consent order is not displayed in prominent locations within the plant. As per regulatory requirements, the consent order must be visibly posted to ensure awareness among employees, contractors, and visitors regarding the plants compliance with environmental norms. However, no such display was found in easily accessible or high-visibility areas such as the main entrance, notice boards, or operational zones. The absence of the consent order in prominent locations may lead to non-compliance with regulatory expectations and limit awareness of key environmental and operational conditions among stakeholders.

supplierActions.finding: Waste management, including proper handling, segregation, and disposal of hazardous and non-hazardous materials, is not being followed by employees at the site.
supplierActions.description: Employees at the site are not following proper waste management practices, including handling, segregation, and disposal of hazardous and non-hazardous materials.

supplierActions.finding: The organization does not have a Permit to Work (PTW) system available for all activities.
supplierActions.description:
The organization does not have a Permit-to-Work (PTW) system in place for all activities. There is no formalized process to ensure risk assessment, authorization, and control measures before executing such high-risk tasks.
Recommendation:
Implement a Permit-to-Work (PTW) System: Establish a PTW system for all high-risk activities, including work on fragile roofs, to ensure proper authorization and risk mitigation.
Conduct Risk Assessments: Ensure that a detailed risk assessment is performed before any work on fragile roofs, identifying hazards and implementing necessary controls.
Implement Fall Protection Measures: Install appropriate fall protection systems such as guardrails, safety harnesses, and fall arrest systems to minimize the risk of falls.
Provide Training & Awareness: Train employees and contractors on the hazards of working with high risk activities
Regular Inspections & Monitoring: Establish a routine inspection process to verify compliance with the PTW system and ensure safety measures are consistently followed.

supplierActions.finding: The organization has not maintained Hazardous and other waste records when the waste is generated.
supplierActions.description:
Audit Observation:
The organization is not maintaining records of hazardous waste in Form-3 as required by regulatory standards. Waste generation should be recorded at the time it occurs, but this practice is not being followed.

Recommendation:
The organization should strengthen its record-keeping practices to ensure that hazardous and other waste is documented at the point of generation. This will improve regulatory compliance, enhance traceability, and support more effective waste management planning.

supplierActions.finding: The organization has not updated the environmental data display board located at the facility entrance.
supplierActions.otherLaw: The Honorable Supreme Court Order dated 14th October 2003
supplierActions.description:
The organization has not updated the environmental data display board located at the facility entrance.
Recommendation:
The organization should ensure timely updates to the environmental data display board to maintain compliance with regulatory requirements and provide accurate information to stakeholders.

supplierActions.finding: The containers holding hazardous waste were not labeled as "Hazardous Waste" as required under Form-8 of the regulatory guidelines.
supplierActions.description:
During the audit, it was observed that the containers holding hazardous waste were not labeled with the required "Hazardous Waste" marking, as specified in Form-8. Proper labeling of hazardous waste containers is essential for ensuring safe handling, storage, and transportation, as well as for compliance with regulatory standards.

Recommendation:
The organization should immediately implement procedures to label all hazardous waste containers with the appropriate "Hazardous Waste" markings, as outlined in Form-8. This is a crucial step to ensure safety, prevent accidents, and maintain regulatory compliance. Proper labeling will also improve waste segregation, facilitate better waste management practices, and help in identifying potential hazards quickly in case of emergencies.

supplierActions.finding: The organization employs 700 workers; however, a well-equipped Occupational Health Centre (OHC), as mandated under the Factories Act, 1948, has not been established.
supplierActions.description:
During the audit, it was observed that the organization employs 700,however, a well-equipped Occupational Health Centre (OHC) has not been established as per the requirements of the Factories Act, 1948. The mandatory presence of a qualified medical officer and paramedical personnel was also not ensured. The absence of a fully functional OHC raises concerns regarding worker health and safety, medical emergency response, and regulatory compliance.

Regulatory Requirement:
As per Factories Act, 1948, and applicable State Factory Rules:
Factories employing 500 or more workers must have a well-equipped Occupational Health Centre (OHC) within the premises.
The OHC should be staffed with a full-time qualified medical officer, supported by paramedical personnel, and equipped with essential first-aid and medical facilities to handle workplace health issues and emergencies.

supplierActions.finding: The organization does not collect, handle, store, or dispose of bio-medical waste in accordance with the Bio-Medical Waste Management (BMWM) Rules, 2016.
supplierActions.description:
The organization does not collect, handle, store, or dispose of bio-medical waste in accordance with the Bio-Medical Waste Management (BMWM) Rules, 2016. No proper segregation, labeling, or disposal procedures were observed during the audit, and no evidence of compliance with regulatory requirements was presented.

Regulatory Requirement:
As per the BMWM Rules, 2016, any facility generating bio-medical waste must:

Segregate waste into designated color-coded containers.
Ensure safe handling and storage to prevent contamination.
Dispose of waste through an authorized bio-medical waste disposal facility.
Maintain records of bio-medical waste generation and disposal.

supplierActions.finding: The organization is not maintaining E-Waste records as required under Form-2 of the E-Waste (Management) Rules, 2022.
supplierActions.description:
The organization is not maintaining E-Waste records as required under Form-2 of the E-Waste (Management) Rules, 2022. Additionally, e-waste has not been disposed of within the stipulated 180-day timeframe from the date of generation. It was also observed that no e-waste disposal was carried out in the previous year.

Regulatory Requirement:
As per the E-Waste (Management) Rules, 2022, organizations generating e-waste must:

Maintain records of e-waste generation and disposal in Form-2.
Dispose of e-waste within 180 days through authorized recyclers or dismantlers.
Ensure timely submission of annual returns to the prescribed authority.

supplierActions.finding: The organization has not established a baseline year for measuring energy productivity
supplierActions.description:
The organization has not established a baseline year for measuring energy productivity, making it difficult to track improvements, set realistic targets, and evaluate energy efficiency initiatives effectively.

Recommendation: The organization should define a baseline year based on historical energy consumption data. This will provide a reference point for measuring progress, identifying trends, and implementing targeted energy management strategies to enhance productivity and sustainability.

supplierActions.finding: The organization has successfully installed solar panels covering 60% of the roof, generating 633 kV of renewable energy.
supplierActions.description: The organization has made significant strides in renewable energy adoption by installing solar panels covering 60% of the roof, with a capacity of 633 kV. This initiative demonstrates a strong commitment to sustainability, reducing reliance on conventional energy sources and contributing to lower carbon emissions. By harnessing solar power, the organization is actively improving energy efficiency and promoting environmentally responsible operations.

supplierActions.finding: The organization currently does not map its Scope 1 and Scope 2 emissions
supplierActions.description: The organization should enhance its environmental sustainability efforts by establishing a structured emissions tracking system. This will enable better assessment of its carbon footprint, identification of key emission sources, and development of effective reduction strategies. Implementing this initiative will improve monitoring, reporting, and compliance with sustainability goals and regulatory requirements, ultimately fostering a more efficient and responsible energy management

supplierActions.finding: Organisation can plans to improve percentage of recycled input material in final product.
supplierActions.description: The organization has the potential to enhance sustainability by increasing the percentage of recycled input materials used in the final product. Implementing a structured plan to source and integrate more recycled materials can help reduce raw material consumption, lower environmental impact, and improve resource efficiency. This initiative can also contribute to cost savings, regulatory compliance, and alignment with circular economy principles. Developing clear strategies, such as supplier engagement, material substitution, and process optimization, will support the organization's commitment to sustainable production.

supplierActions.finding: The organization does not currently have a recoverability process in place for the waste generated. Without a structured waste recovery system, valuable materials that could be reused or recycled may be lost, leading to increased waste disposal costs and environmental impact.
supplierActions.description: An opportunity exists to improve waste management practices by implementing a structured waste recovery system. This would help reduce landfill disposal, maximize resource efficiency, and minimize environmental impact. Adopting strategies such as waste segregation, material recovery, and collaboration with recycling partners can strengthen sustainability efforts, ensure regulatory compliance, and lead to cost savings in waste disposal.

supplierActions.finding: The organization has successfully designed and implemented a mechanized trolley system for storing and transporting materials.
supplierActions.description: The organization has successfully designed and implemented a mechanized trolley system for storing and transporting materials from their plant to clients. This initiative has eliminated the need for packaging materials, significantly reducing waste, improving sustainability, and enhancing operational efficiency.

supplierActions.finding: Confined spaces within the facility have not been identified, and essential safety measures, including adequate ventilation and protective equipment, are not in place to ensure worker safety.
supplierActions.description:
The organization has not yet identified confined spaces, leading to non-compliance with legal requirements under The Factories Act, 1948 (Section 36) and IS 14489:2018 (Code of Practice on Occupational Safety and Health Audit). The absence of confined space identification presents serious safety risks, including potential exposure to oxygen-deficient atmospheres, toxic gases, and other hazardous conditions.
Mapping of confined spaces within the facility should be conducted, and a maintained list should be established.

supplierActions.finding: The fire pumps and fire hydrants were found to be non-operational due to the impairment of the jockey pump.
supplierActions.otherLaw: National Building Code of India (NBC), 2016  Part 4 (Fire and Life Safety)
supplierActions.description:
Non-Conformance (NC): The fire pumps and fire hydrants were found to be non-operational due to the impairment of the jockey pump. This poses a significant fire safety risk, as the firefighting system may not function effectively in the event of an emergency, compromising the safety of personnel and property.

Recommendation: Immediate corrective action should be taken to repair or replace the jockey pump and restore full functionality of the fire pumps and hydrants. A preventive maintenance plan should be implemented to regularly inspect and test the firefighting system to ensure compliance with fire safety regulations and emergency preparedness.

supplierActions.finding: The pathway to the fire hydrant post is obstructed by plantation,
supplierActions.otherLaw: National Building Code of India (NBC), 2016  Part 4 (Fire and Life Safety): Requires that access to firefighting equipment, including hydrants, remain unobstructed at all times to ensure emergency readiness.
supplierActions.description:
The pathway to the fire hydrant post is obstructed by plantation, which can delay access and hinder firefighting operations during an emergency. This non-compliance poses a serious fire safety risk, potentially increasing response time and jeopardizing the safety of personnel and property.

Immediate action should be taken to clear the obstructing plantation and ensure an unobstructed pathway to the fire hydrant. A routine inspection and maintenance plan should be established to prevent any future obstructions, ensuring compliance with fire safety regulations and enhancing emergency preparedness.

supplierActions.finding: Onsite emergency preparedness plan is not maintained at the plant.
supplierActions.description:
The organization currently does not have a maintained onsite emergency preparedness plan. Establishing and regularly updating a comprehensive emergency preparedness plan would enhance the organization's ability to effectively respond to emergencies, minimize risks, and ensure the safety of employees and assets.

Recommendation: The organization should develop a structured onsite emergency preparedness plan, including risk assessment, emergency response procedures, evacuation protocols, firefighting measures, and regular drills. Regular training and periodic reviews should be conducted to ensure its effectiveness and compliance with legal and safety requirements.

supplierActions.finding: Evacuation plans are not displayed across the overall plant area
supplierActions.otherLaw: National Building Code of India (NBC) 2016  Part 4 (Fire and Life Safety)
supplierActions.description:
Evacuation plans are not displayed across the overall plant area, which can lead to confusion and delays during emergencies, posing a risk to employee safety.

Recommendation: The organization should install clearly visible evacuation plans across all critical areas of the plant. Regular drills should be conducted to ensure all employees are familiar with evacuation routes and emergency procedures.

supplierActions.finding: Shopfloor workers are not included as committee members.
supplierActions.description:
The safety committee members have been nominated; however, shop floor workers are not included as committee members. Excluding shop floor workers may result in inadequate representation of worker safety concerns and hinder effective implementation of workplace safety measures.

The organization should revise the composition of the safety committee to include shopfloor workers as members, ensuring proper representation as per legal requirements. This will enhance worker participation in safety discussions, improve hazard reporting, and contribute to a safer working environment.

supplierActions.finding: The Local Exhaust Ventilation (LEV) arrangement is not available in the welding and machining areas
supplierActions.description:
The Local Exhaust Ventilation (LEV) arrangement is not available in the welding and machining areas, which may lead to increased exposure to hazardous fumes, dust, and airborne contaminants. Prolonged exposure can pose serious health risks, including respiratory issues and long-term occupational illnesses.

Installation of LEV Systems  Implement appropriate fume extraction systems at welding and machining stations to effectively capture and remove airborne contaminants at the source.
Regular Air Quality MonitoringConduct periodic assessments of indoor air quality to ensure compliance with permissible exposure limits (PELs) as per regulatory standards.
Implementing these control measures will enhance workplace air quality, ensure compliance with health and safety regulations, and protect workers from potential health hazards.

supplierActions.finding: Training sessions on Energy Conservation, Waste Management, Road Safety, and Biodiversity Preservation have not been conducted for employees.
supplierActions.description:
There is a lack of structured training programs on energy conservation, waste management, road safety, and biodiversity preservation for employees. Without proper awareness and capacity building, employees may not fully understand their role in sustainability efforts, leading to inefficiencies, non-compliance with environmental regulations, and missed opportunities for resource optimization.

Recommended Actions:
1. Energy Conservation Training:
Educate employees on energy-saving techniques such as efficient use of lighting and office equipment.
Conduct awareness sessions on renewable energy integration, carbon footprint reduction, and energy-efficient workplace practices.
Train facility teams on energy monitoring systems and best practices in energy audits.
2. Waste Management Awareness:
Provide detailed training on waste segregation at source, recycling processes, and waste minimization strategies.
Implement a zero waste to landfill initiative by engaging employees in proper disposal methods and sustainable alternatives.
Conduct practical sessions on E-waste handling, hazardous waste disposal, and composting for organic waste.
3. Road Safety Programs:
Organize defensive driving training, pedestrian safety workshops, and emergency response drills for employees and drivers.
Train employees on vehicle maintenance for fuel efficiency and accident prevention.
Implement safe commuting guidelines for employees using personal or public transport.
4. Biodiversity Conservation Training:
Educate employees on the impact of industrial activities on local biodiversity and ways to mitigate ecological damage.
Conduct tree plantation drives, awareness sessions on wildlife conservation, and sustainable landscaping practices.
Train employees on reducing water consumption, preventing soil erosion, and protecting natural resources near operational sites.
5. Integration & Continuous Engagement:
Embed sustainability training into the EHS induction program for all new employees.
Conduct periodic refresher training and sustainability challenges to encourage active participation.
Establish sustainability champions within teams to promote best practices and monitor compliance.

supplierActions.finding: Discrepancy between installed DG sets (8) and consent document (6).
supplierActions.description: Discrepancy between installed DG sets (8) and consent document (6). As per the rules, particularly the regulations set by the Air (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act, 1981, any equipment that has the potential to cause pollution, including DG sets (diesel generator sets), must be specifically mentioned and approved in the Consent to Operate (CTO) issued by the TNPCB.

supplierActions.finding: No secondary containers for chemical tins; compatibility chart is missing.
supplierActions.description: During the inspection, secondary containment for chemical storage tins was not available, posing risks of spills and contamination. Additionally, a chemical compatibility chart was missing, increasing the risk of hazardous reactions. Both are essential for safe storage, compliance, and spill control, requiring immediate corrective action to prevent potential hazards.

supplierActions.finding: Competent personnel have been assigned for operating critical equipment.
supplierActions.description: Competent personnel have been assigned for operating critical equipment, ensuring safe and efficient handling. This proactive approach enhances workplace safety, operational reliability, and regulatory adherence.

supplierActions.finding: Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for diesel is not available in the Diesel Generator (DG) room
supplierActions.description:
The Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for diesel is not available in the Diesel Generator (DG) room, presenting an opportunity for improvement. MSDS is an essential document that provides detailed information about the hazards, safe handling practices, emergency response procedures, and storage requirements for hazardous materials like diesel.

The absence of the MSDS could lead to unsafe handling, storage, and emergency responses in the event of spills, leaks, or accidents. It is recommended to ensure that the MSDS for diesel is readily available in the DG room, easily accessible to all personnel working in that area. Regular training on the handling of hazardous materials and the importance of MSDS should also be conducted. This will ensure compliance with safety regulations and improve overall safety standards.

supplierActions.finding: Smoke detector system is not available in the Diesel Generator (DG) room and critical areas such as the transformer area and electrical panel rooms
supplierActions.description:
The smoke detector system is not available in the Diesel Generator (DG) room and critical areas such as the transformer area and electrical panel rooms, presenting a significant safety concern.

According to safety regulations, including NFPA 72 and IS 2189, smoke detectors should be installed in areas where fire hazards are high, including electrical and transformer rooms, to ensure early detection of smoke or fire. The absence of smoke detection systems in these critical areas increases the risk of delayed fire detection, potentially leading to serious consequences.

It is recommended to install smoke detectors in the DG room, transformer area, and electrical panel rooms to comply with fire safety regulations. Regular checks, maintenance, and testing of the smoke detection system should be conducted to ensure its functionality. Additionally, employees should be trained in fire safety protocols and emergency response actions. This will improve the overall fire safety preparedness and compliance with industry standards.

supplierActions.finding: Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) has not been carried out
supplierActions.description:
The Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) has not been carried out, presenting an opportunity for improvement.
LCA is a valuable tool that evaluates the environmental impact of a product or process throughout its entire life cycle, from raw material extraction to production, usage, and disposal. The absence of an LCA means that the organization may not have a clear understanding of the full environmental impacts of its products or processes, making it challenging to identify areas for improvement or opportunities to reduce environmental footprint.
It is recommended to implement LCA for key products or processes within the organization. Conducting LCA will provide valuable insights into resource consumption, emissions, waste generation, and other environmental impacts, allowing the company to make more informed decisions. This will also help in identifying opportunities for resource efficiency, energy conservation, and waste reduction, contributing to the organizations sustainability goals.

supplierActions.finding: BMW Authorization is not available
supplierActions.description: Bio-Medical Waste Authorization is not available. As per the Bio-Medical Waste Management Rules, 2016, any entity generating bio-medical waste must obtain authorization from the State Pollution Control Board (SPCB). Even if the company generates a very small quantity of bio-medical waste (BMW).

supplierActions.finding: The company submitted Form-4 but omitted Bio-Medical Waste (BMW) details.
supplierActions.description: The company has submitted Form-4, but it has not included information on Bio-Medical Waste (BMW). Entity generating bio-medical waste must submit an annual report in Form-4 to the State Pollution Control Board (SPCB) by June 30th each year.

supplierActions.finding: Plastic waste authorization is not obtained

supplierActions.finding: Discrepancy between installed DG sets (8) and consent document (6).
supplierActions.description: Discrepancy between installed DG sets (8) and consent document (6).
